resources.string: This application\'s purpose is to provide a tutorial guide on how to learn MySQL. This was a project that was given to us in our application development subject, and we were tasked with creating computer-aided instructions for any of the IT subjects.

\u25CF Table Create \n\u25CF Inserting Data from Table

MySQL Introduction


MySQL is a relational database management system based on the Structured Query Language (SQL), which is a programming language used for managing and accessing records of databases. MySQL is an open-source and free software under the GNU license supported by the Oracle Company.


What is Database?


Database is an application that stores the organized collection of records. It can be easily managed and accessed by the user. It enables us to organize data in the form of tables, rows, columns and indexes to find relevant information very quickly. For conducting database operations like creating, managing, accessing, and searching the data it stores, each database has a unique API. There are numerous databases available today, including Sybase, MySQL, Oracle, MongoDB, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, and more.


Creating Database


When creating database the syntax used will be: CREATE DATABASE database_name


replace the "database_name" with your ideal database name.


for example:


CREATE DATABASE ITeach


Done! (thumbs up)

Table is used to organized data in a structured format by arranging data in rows and columns. This is similar to worksheets in the spreadsheet program. Two requirements are usually needed for a table creation command:


○ Name of the table 
○ Name of fields 
○ Definition for each field (Optional)


Before creating a table, it is important to note that a database should be selected first to direct the table inside the database.
n
\When creating database the syntax used will be:


CREATE TABLE table_name( 
column_specification1, 
column_specification2, 
......, 
table_constraints(optional) 
) 

Example:


CREATE TABLE users( 
UserID VARCHAR(5), 
LName VARCHAR(255), 
FName VARCHAR(255), 
Adress VARCHAR(100), 
Age INT, 
PRIMARY KEY(UserID) 
)


Inserting data from table


There are two ways in inserting data to a table.


The first option is using the SET command. Here we use the syntax:


INSERT INTO table_name 
SET 
col_name1=value1 
col_name2=value2 
... 

Using the SET command, it is important to specify the column's name. The user may even skip other columns if there is no data needed to be added to the column.


Unlike the SET command, VALUES does not need to specify the column's name; instead, it depends on how the column is structured.


Just like before, we will be using the user table for this example.


INSERT INTO users 
VALUES( 
'00101', 
'Dizon', 
'Isaac Rossdale', 
NULL, 
20 
)


Because the VALUES command is dependent on how the column was constructed, the user needs to insert data in every column in order for it to work. In the case of skipping a column, the user can place NULL inside said columns to leave them empty.

In table manipulation, also called alter table, we can change the table structure depending on some situations that may require you to change the structure. 

This is the list of commands that you can use:


● Add Column 
● Modify Column 
● Rename/Change Column 
● Drop Column 
● Add Index 
● Drop Index 
● Add Constraint 
● Drop Constraint


► Add Column Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName ADD columnName Data Type

ALTER TABLE users ADD Sex VARCHAR(6)


► Modify Column Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName MODIFY columnname NewDataType

ALTER TABLE users MODIFY Address CHAR(123)


► Rename Column Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName CHANGE columnnName newColumnName DataType


► Drop Column Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName DROP columnname

ALTER TABLE users DROP Age


► Add Index Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName ADD INDEX INDEX-NAME (columnname)

ALTER TABLE users ADD INDEX IDX_Surname (LName)


► Drop Index Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName DROP INDEX INDEX_NAME

ALTER TABLE users DROP INDEX IDX_Surname


► Add Constraint Syntax


The constraint specifies the start definition for our three types that we can apply, which are:


○ PRIMARY KEY - It enforces an entity for a specified column or columns by using a unique index. Only one can exist for each table.


○ UNIQUE - provides entity integrity for a specified column or column by using a unique index.


○ FOREIGN KEY - provides referential integrity for the data in the column. It requires that each value in the column exist in the specified column in the reference table.


► Add Constraint Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName ADD CONSTRAINT [ConstraintName] [ConstraintType] [ConstraintCondition]

ALTER TABLE users ADD CONSTRAINT CON_Sex UNIQUE (Sex)


► Drop Constaint Syntax


ALTER TABLE TableName DROP [ConstraintName/Index] [ConstraintName]


ALTER TABLE users DROP CON_Sex


The added Constraint will be deleted when the DROP command is used

There are times when the user needs to change data from the table; this can be achieved with the use of the UPDATE command.


This is the Syntax for the UPDATE command:


UPDATE table_name 
SET column1 = value1, 
column2 = value 2 
… 
WHERE condition;


Here is an example of the UPDATE command changing the data from our example of the INSERT FROM SET.


UPDATE users 
SET UserID = '00102', 
LName = 'Vilaga', 
FName = 'Arwin Paul', 
Address = 'Baras', 
Age = 19 
WHERE UserID = '00100'


With the use of WHERE, the user can specify which row or column of data will be changed. In this case, all the data in the row where the UserID is "00100" will be changed.


DELETE


With the use of the DELETE command, inserted data can be deleted, as the name suggests. Here is the syntax for the DELETE command:


DELETE FROM table_Name 
WHERE condition


Here is an example with the table based again on the INSERT FROM SET example:


DELETE FROM users 
WHERE Age = 19


This command will delete the whole row of every field that has 19 as the inserted data for age.


If the user wants to delete all the items in the table without deleting the table itself, the DELETE command can be used in an alternative way:


DELETE FROM table_name


Here is an example:


DELETE FROM users


This will delete all the data that was inserted into the table but not the table itself.
1. What is the meaning of SQL
Application that stores organized collection of records
Application that creates simple solution for complex problems
4. This symbol use to apply space on database name
5. It is a relational database management system based on SQL
1. _____ is used to organized data in a structured format by arranging data in rows and columns.
2. it is important to note that a database should be _____ first to direct the table inside the database.
3. This command is the another way of inserting the data to a table
4. Unlike the SET command, VALUES need to specify the column\'s name.
5. This is the another way of inserting the command that does not need to specify the column\'s names.
1. Manipulating the table is also called as _____
2. This command allows you to add a new column on the table
3. Command that allows you to add new index
4. Allows you to change the variable type on the table
5. Allows you to remove a constraint on the table
1. Used to revise/change data from the table.
2. With the use of ______, the user can specify which row or column of data will be changed.
3. This command used to delete the inserted data.
4. This is how you delete all the items without deleting the table itself.
